channel.title: No newbies please
channel.description: Well since anyone I ask on msn wont say anything and pups isnt around anymore, does anyone know the general pusedo code of the boxsolver.dll by pups? we managed to do everything that srl does for the box solver more effciently(like acutally getting the flat side the first time it shows), but i have no clue on how to process a rotated object with deformaties. if anyone has an idea on how pups did it that would be very apperciated. or for a way to contact pups so i could message him.

item.title: No newbies please
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:18, topic:26224”]I have to admit that I downloaded the source file out of sheer, morbid curiousity. That sure is a great deal of work just to solve the ‘strange box’.

Why not just hook the ‘main context[sup]1[/sup]’ array and grab index 312. The value in that array is -1 until a strange box interface is open. That int is the entire encoding of the strange box itself (yes, faces and all). Of course, you will have to figure out the encoding yourself. Once you figure it out, imagine the thrill of being able to say ‘I did it myself with only limited help.’ Keep in mind that this approach requires you to grab a single runtime hook and access it. Read only. No writes needed. For a hybrid system, this is almost a necessity as this concept will give you the ability to solve a vast majority of the random events deemed ‘unsolvable’ in scar or scar-esque systems.

Of course, for those of you that insist on doing things the hard way, feel free to continue using a hammer to try and screw a bolt into a slab of concrete, as this post is less for you than those that develop internal or even hybrid systems.

[sup]1[/sup] main context array is the name that I give it. It seems to hold various tidbits of data that the game would need quick access to… ie. run/walk state, attack type, etc. It reminded me of a webserver context and so it was named.[/quote]

Ok. Thanks for that tip. We found the array, figured the encoding (surprisingly easy) and we now have a full anti stange box random :). So, thankyou for that tip

Read full topic

item.title: No newbies please
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

lol.

I just reread my post and noticed that I inadvertantly smacked you with that blanket statement. While you have a point that they could change the index to 312, keep in mind that I had to look it up as any good system would not rely on a static number. The only thing it needs to know is that a value changes and when the value change notification comes in, if it is within the valid range, it is accepted, otherwise it is discarded.

You have a point with ‘unsolvable’. I should have qualified that. As an aside, have you ever said something knowing full well what you meant, but wanted to get it out and in the process left out a validating point? There is nothing that is impossible. Everything is possible given infinite time and patience. My threshold is much lower than infinite. I call things ‘unsolvable’ or ‘impossible’ if it is past my threshold. Is it vain? Sure. Do I care? Nope.

As for my critical nature? It’s a weakness of mine. I didn’t mean to critique you, personally, it just came out that way. I have obvious reasons for rejecting any form of OCR. The main reason is that there would be no possible way to do with OCR what is being done with internal systems. ie… 2-8% cpu utilization, 50+ bots per system, high efficiency, high volume, etc. When I say no way, in this sense I mean it. The game itself limits you. In a nutshell, you or anyone else from what I have seen, will never be able to have a pure ocr solution that can run more than a menial number of bots on the same system. The cpu and resource usage is just too high.

Next question about releasing my work. I am under an NDA that restricts me from speaking too much about any possible system I may or may not have written. But, not being able to talk to really anyone about what I do, I enjoy ‘checking up’ on various other sites to find out if anyone has progressed to a point that would require me to make any significant changes to my system.

I have not seen anything worrying yet.

And by the way, 56.7 degrees is far too cold.

Read full topic

item.title: No newbies please
item.dc:creator: @benland100 benland100
item.description:
@benland100 wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:18, topic:26224”]I have to admit that I downloaded the source file out of sheer, morbid curiousity. That sure is a great deal of work just to solve the ‘strange box’.

Why not just hook the ‘main context[sup]1[/sup]’ array and grab index 312. The value in that array is -1 until a strange box interface is open. That int is the entire encoding of the strange box itself (yes, faces and all). Of course, you will have to figure out the encoding yourself. Once you figure it out, imagine the thrill of being able to say ‘I did it myself with only limited help.’ Keep in mind that this approach requires you to grab a single runtime hook and access it. Read only. No writes needed. For a hybrid system, this is almost a necessity as this concept will give you the ability to solve a vast majority of the random events deemed ‘unsolvable’ in scar or scar-esque systems.

Of course, for those of you that insist on doing things the hard way, feel free to continue using a hammer to try and screw a bolt into a slab of concrete, as this post is less for you than those that develop internal or even hybrid systems.

[sup]1[/sup] main context array is the name that I give it. It seems to hold various tidbits of data that the game would need quick access to… ie. run/walk state, attack type, etc. It reminded me of a webserver context and so it was named.[/quote]
I’ll tell you exactly why I prefer my hammer to any pair of pliers or wrench you can provide. Simply, I get more joy out of writing a computer vision algorithm (however basic it is) then a simple decoding of an integer value in the client. I have a good reason for this, at least I think it is a good reason, I welcome yours: while Jagex could very well change the graphical design of the box, wouldn’t it be easier to change the strange box index to 313, or any other value for that matter? It makes more sense to me to make something that is harder for them to break.

Also, I’m sure you mistyped when you called something unsolvable; as I’m sure you know that anything is possible if you’re willing to put the time and effort into it. As you are so critical of other people’s work, why not show off some of your own work which, no doubt, is millions of years beyond the rest of us, and as that may be, you might refuse just to keep our heads from exploding while trying to comprehend it.

Once again, I’m surprised that you consider this a lot of work. It took me all of two, maybe three, afternoons as a side project because I was bored and decided to do someone a favor. Please take the time to consider that, just because your way is superior to all others, someone might want to do it differently just for the experience. While I use my hammer to screw a bolt into concrete, you continue to use your surgical scalpel to cut the crust off of your, precisely measured, peanut butter and jelly sandwich, prepared at exactly 56.7 degrees fahrenheit. Have fun with that sandwich

P.S. Thanks for the support, I don’t know what we would ever do without you. I guess we would have to invent fire all by ourselves.

Read full topic

item.title: No newbies please
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

I have to admit that I downloaded the source file out of sheer, morbid curiousity. That sure is a great deal of work just to solve the ‘strange box’.

Why not just hook the ‘main context[sup]1[/sup]’ array and grab index 312. The value in that array is -1 until a strange box interface is open. That int is the entire encoding of the strange box itself (yes, faces and all). Of course, you will have to figure out the encoding yourself. Once you figure it out, imagine the thrill of being able to say ‘I did it myself with only limited help.’ Keep in mind that this approach requires you to grab a single runtime hook and access it. Read only. No writes needed. For a hybrid system, this is almost a necessity as this concept will give you the ability to solve a vast majority of the random events deemed ‘unsolvable’ in scar or scar-esque systems.

Of course, for those of you that insist on doing things the hard way, feel free to continue using a hammer to try and screw a bolt into a slab of concrete, as this post is less for you than those that develop internal or even hybrid systems.

[sup]1[/sup] main context array is the name that I give it. It seems to hold various tidbits of data that the game would need quick access to… ie. run/walk state, attack type, etc. It reminded me of a webserver context and so it was named.

item.title: No newbies please
item.dc:creator: @benland100 benland100
item.description:
@benland100 wrote:

Ok, I can do the shapes 100%, but the numbers are not so easy. I can tell if it is an 8, 0, 4, or 1. i can tell if it is a 6 or 9 but not always which one. 2, and 3 i am almost sure on. 5, 7 i need more screenshots of.

So, if anyone wants to give me a lot of box screenshots (preferably in .png format) i’ll tweek it and it will be done. (I’ll edit this and post what I’ve got done after a bit)

Read full topic

item.title: No newbies please
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

i am not stuck, i just havn’t been working on it in a 2 week.

track back:
http://www.villu-reborn.com/showthread.php?t=4061

My current idea is to find the biggest piece of white. That i can do. Take the area of the white. That i can do.

Then i know the shape in theory. (lol)

Now for the orc.

I was thinking of taking every point in the number and comparing it to the other numbers, find the 2 points that are furtest away from each other in terms of distance transversed while staying the the letter.

ex:
Code:
*xx
x
ox
x
*xx

to get from * to * every X is tranversed and added to the distance. The o is not transvered

Distance = 8;
dx = 4, dy =0

So now in theory we have a better idea of how the number is aligned.

The rest i am stilling thinking about.

Any suggestions? any critisms?

import java.awt.Rectangle;
import java.io.IOException;

import impsoft.ibot.Areas;
import impsoft.ibot.Info;

import impsoft.ibot.core.SettingsManager;
import impsoft.ibot.managers.BitMapManger;
import impsoft.ibot.methods.Menu;
import impsoft.ibot.methods.NPCChat;
import impsoft.ibot.methods.RGB;
import impsoft.ibot.methods.Random;
import impsoft.ibot.methods.XY;

public class StrangeBox extends Random {
    private short[][][] box;

    private XY matches[];

    public String author = "ruler, pups";

    public boolean startUp() {
        if (theBot.loggedIn) {
            if (box == null) {
                box = loadBitmap("bitmaps/strangebox.bmp");
            }
            if (getTab() == Info.TAB_INVENTORY) {
                matches = findXYs(getColorArray2d(), Areas.INVENTORY, null,
                        box, null, 30, 5, 5, 5);
                if (matches.length > 0) {
                    return true;
                }
            }
            NPCChat chat = null;
            try {
                chat = getNPCChat(0);
            } catch (InterruptedException e) {
            }
            if (chat != null
                    && chat.options.length == 3
                    && chat.options[0]
                            .contains("You have been given a Mysterious box")) {
                return true;
            }
        }
        setNextCheck(3000);
        return false;
    }

    public XY findText(String text) {
        return findGameScreenText(text, Areas.GAME, new RGB(187, 185, 73), 3,
                3, 3);
    }

    public String shapes[] = { "Pentagon", "Circle", "Square", "Star",
            "Triangle" };

    public void random() throws InterruptedException {
        NPCChat chat = null;
        try {
            chat = getNPCChat(0);
        } catch (InterruptedException e) {
        }
        if (chat != null
                && chat.options.length == 3
                && chat.options[0]
                        .contains("You have been given a Mysterious box")) {
            chat.selectContains("Click Here");
            sleep(1000);
        }
        if (getTab() != Info.TAB_INVENTORY) {
            setTab(Info.TAB_INVENTORY);
            sleep(1500);
        }
        if (getTab() == Info.TAB_INVENTORY) {
            matches = findXYs(getColorArray2d(), Areas.INVENTORY, null, box,
                    null, 30, 5, 5, 5);
        }
        for (int i = 0; i < matches.length; i++) {
            mouseClickRight(new Rectangle(matches[i].x, matches[i].y,
                    box.length, box[0].length));
            Menu menu = getMenu(Areas.INVENTORY, 2000);
            if (menu != null) {
                boolean success = menu.selectContains("Open");
                if (success) {
                    while (true) {
                        sleep(3000);
                        // What question
                        if (findText("What") != null) {
                            whatQuestion();
                        }
                        // Which question
                        else if (findText("Which") != null) {
                            whichQuestion();
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
            // log("Found boxes at | X " + matches[i].x + " | Y " +
            // matches[i].y);
        }

        // log("Box Found Kill Bot");
        // shutDown();
    }

    public void whatQuestion() throws InterruptedException {
        int shapeIndex = -1;
        for (int shp = 0; shp < shapes.length; shp++) {
            if (findText("" + shapes[shp]) != null) {
                shapeIndex = shp;
                break;
            }
        }
        if (shapeIndex != -1) {
            int options[] = new int[3];
            int found = 0;
            for (int num = 0; num < 10; num++) {
                if (findText("" + num) != null) {
                    options[found] = num;
                    found++;
                    if (found == 3)
                        break;
                }
            }
            if (found == 3) {
                log("Which number is the " + shapes[shapeIndex]);
                for (int option = 0; option < options.length; option++) {
                    log("     " + options[option]);
                }
                // TODO
            }
        } else {
            log("Could not determine the shape to find");
        }
    }

    public void whichQuestion() throws InterruptedException {
        int numerToFind = -1;
        for (int num = 0; num < 10; num++) {
            if (findText("" + num) != null) {
                numerToFind = num;
                break;
            }
        }
        if (numerToFind != -1) {
            int options[] = new int[3];
            int found = 0;
            for (int shp = 0; shp < shapes.length; shp++) {
                if (findText("" + shapes[shp]) != null) {
                    options[found] = shp;
                    found++;
                    if (found == 3)
                        break;
                }
            }
            if (found == 3) {
                log("Which shape has a " + numerToFind);
                for (int option = 0; option < options.length; option++) {
                    log("      " + shapes[options[option]]);
                }
                long time = System.currentTimeMillis();
                while (true) {
                    sleep(50);
                    getColorArray2d(0);// reresh color
                    // array
                    if (findRGBXYs(getColorArray2d(), new Rectangle(182, 45, 1,
                            180), null, new RGB(16579837, RGB.COLOR_TYPE_SCAR),
                            1, 5, 5, 5).length > 0) {
                        continue;
                    }
                    if (findRGBXYs(getColorArray2d(), new Rectangle(342, 45, 1,
                            180), null, new RGB(16579837, RGB.COLOR_TYPE_SCAR),
                            1, 5, 5, 5).length > 0) {
                        continue;
                    }
                    if (findRGBXYs(getColorArray2d(), new Rectangle(172, 55,
                            177, 1), null, new RGB(16579837,
                            RGB.COLOR_TYPE_SCAR), 1, 5, 5, 5).length > 0) {
                        continue;
                    }
                    if (findRGBXYs(getColorArray2d(), new Rectangle(172, 215,
                            177, 1), null, new RGB(16579837,
                            RGB.COLOR_TYPE_SCAR), 1, 5, 5, 5).length > 0) {
                        continue;
                    }
                    if (findRGBXYs(getColorArray2d(), new Rectangle(182, 45, 1,
                            180), null, new RGB(12764106, RGB.COLOR_TYPE_SCAR),
                            1, 5, 5, 5).length > 0) {
                        continue;
                    }
                    if (findRGBXYs(getColorArray2d(), new Rectangle(342, 45, 1,
                            180), null, new RGB(12764106, RGB.COLOR_TYPE_SCAR),
                            1, 5, 5, 5).length > 0) {
                        continue;
                    }
                    if (findRGBXYs(getColorArray2d(), new Rectangle(172, 55,
                            177, 1), null, new RGB(12764106,
                            RGB.COLOR_TYPE_SCAR), 1, 5, 5, 5).length > 0) {
                        continue;
                    }
                    if (findRGBXYs(getColorArray2d(), new Rectangle(172, 215,
                            1, 180), null, new RGB(12764106,
                            RGB.COLOR_TYPE_SCAR), 1, 5, 5, 5).length > 0) {
                        continue;
                    }
                    break;
                }
                log("Took " + (System.currentTimeMillis() - time)
                        + " ms to complete pup's pre-function ");
                short[][][] colors = getColorArray2d(1000);
                XY center = new XY(239, 157);
                Rectangle rec = new Rectangle(center.x - 20, center.y - 20, 40,
                        40);
                XY whiteCenter = findXYspiral(colors, rec, null, center.x,
                        center.y, new RGB(255, 255, 255), 15, 15, 15);
                if (whiteCenter == null)
                    whiteCenter = findXYspiral(colors, rec, null, center.x,
                            center.y, new RGB(255, 255, 255), 30, 30, 30);
                if (whiteCenter == null)
                    whiteCenter = findXYspiral(colors, rec, null, center.x,
                            center.y, new RGB(255, 255, 255), 60, 60, 60);
                int trues = 0;
                // //TODO
                // much of the stuff below is garbage
                if (whiteCenter != null) {
                    RGB color = new RGB(colors[whiteCenter.x][whiteCenter.y]);
                    boolean matches[][] = new boolean[SettingsManager.maxX][SettingsManager.maxY];
                    int x, y;
                    int maxX, maxY;
                    maxX = SettingsManager.maxX;
                    maxY = SettingsManager.maxY;
                    for (x = 0; x < maxX; x++) {
                        for (y = 0; y < maxY; y++) {
                            matches[x][y] = false;
                        }
                    }
                    findMatched(center.x, center.y, matches, colors, color);

                    for (x = 0; x < maxX; x++) {
                        for (y = 0; y < maxY; y++) {
                            if (matches[x][y]) {
                                trues++;
                            }
                        }
                    }
                    log("trues=" + trues);
                }

                try {
                    BitMapManger.write(theBot.theBitMapManger
                            .getBufferedImage(100), "./QQQ" + trues + "QQQ"
                            + +System.currentTimeMillis() + ".bmp");
                } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
                    exception(e);
                } catch (IOException e) {
                    exception(e);
                }
                log("test STOP");
            }
        } else {
            log("Could not determine the number to find");
        }

    }

    public void findMatched(int x, int y, boolean bools[][],
            short colors[][][], RGB color) {
        if (!bools[x][y]) {
            if (colors[x][y][0] == color.r && colors[x][y][1] == color.g
                    && colors[x][y][2] == color.b) {
                bools[x][y] = true;
                findMatched(x + 1, y, bools, colors, color);
                findMatched(x - 1, y, bools, colors, color);
                findMatched(x, y + 1, bools, colors, color);
                findMatched(x, y - 1, bools, colors, color);
            }
        }
    }
}

Read full topic

item.title: No newbies please
item.dc:creator: @benland100 benland100
item.description:
@benland100 wrote:

Well, the basic approach that he took was thus:

  1. Find the largest single color area, assume that is the shape
  2. Find the edge of that area, that is the outline of that shape
  3. Count the number of vertecies on the shape, you now know what the shape is (I know a way to do this, but it dosen’t look like its what pups did)
  4. Assume that the only other color area within the shape is the number
  5. Find the border of that colored area (the number)
  6. I’m a bit sketchy on how to continue from here and will have to think on it more… But, basicly you determin the number from the outline that you have.

Assuming that this is for java, I might be able to write a mock up box solver over the next couple of days, everything minus the numbers anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: No newbies please
item.dc:creator: @benland100 benland100
item.description:
@benland100 wrote:

I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but the reason no one can tell you how it works is no one really knows how pups did it. All he would let on to is that it had something to do with a “Depth First Search” i’ll read up on it if you like. Pups never acutaly said how he did it… aparently none of us were good enough to be told

If you know what you are talking about, go on, fix it. Hope you realize you talk rubbish, after you try, hf.
P.S. Pups and I did not and will not ever like each other or get along just for the record.
